198065: Izzet Steam Maze.author: Etsap
198065: Izzet Steam Maze.text_parsed: I hate the tension between the abilities.  If you have a great spell in your hand, of course you want it to cost 3 less, but then you don't want to accidentally roll planeswalk instead and lose the doubling benefit.  If you don't have a decent spell in hand and just want to leave, then rolling the chaos is useless.  It isn't good when rolling the planar die isn't all upside for the person rolling.
198065: Izzet Steam Maze.text_posted: I hate the tension between the abilities.  If you have a great spell in your hand, of course you want it to cost 3 less, but then you don't want to accidentally roll planeswalk instead and lose the doubling benefit.  If you don't have a decent spell in hand and just want to leave, then rolling the chaos is useless.  It isn't good when rolling the planar die isn't all upside for the person rolling.

198065: Izzet Steam Maze.author: Gandlodder
198065: Izzet Steam Maze.text_parsed:
@Etsap: I couldn't disagree more. So much of the Risk vs. Reward gameplay that made Magic so interesting in the past is being replaced with your vision of "all upside" nonsense that makes for absolutely no significant decisions when building a deck. Cards, such as this one, that offer great power with an associated risk, are much more interesting than cards that simply say "Creatures you control get +1/+1" or "Copy each instant or sorcery you cast" and such.
Besides the more interesting mechanics and choices involved with using this plane, it really fits the Izzet guild flavorfully. Why choose an old reliable Steam Maze that simply copies your spells when you could possibly blow the place up while trying to increase efficiency? The Izzet are always blowing themselves up in pursuit of greatness, why should visitors to their Steam Maze be any different?

198066: Feeding Grounds.author: Etsap
198066: Feeding Grounds.text_parsed: Unlike some color-biased planes, this one doesn't provide a huge swing for the player in the right colors, only a minor bonus.  It does provide a problem for the creatureless player trying to roll away, as an accidental chaos roll forces an enhancement of an opponent's creature much like on Bant.  Still, targeting a token makes X=0, so at least there are usually some fairly neutral options.  Overall though the plane tends to have very little impact on most games, which is sad.

198067: The Hippodrome.author: Arachibutyrophobia
198067: The Hippodrome.text_parsed:
So, if everything on this plane is 1/100 if it's original size, that means that leviathans are about 2000 feet long. (Segovian Leviathan is supposed to be the size of an elephant, which is about 20 feet long)

However, if you think about it, if there was no size reference on the plane, then it wouldn't matter how big things are because everything would be in proportion. Just because it shrinks a creature doesn't mean it's making the creature weaker. And if each plane is it's own individual universe with it's own dimensions and all that crazy stuff, then size would be irrelevant from plane to plane. Size wouldn't exist. But who cares...it's an awesome card with great mechanics! :)

198067: The Hippodrome.author: Ideatog
198067: The Hippodrome.text_parsed:
@ Arachibutyrophobia

Indeed! The leviathan would be just a "normal" leviathan on Segovia. However, it is small in game terms because it is assumed that you are summoning it to some plane other than Segovia, where it is seen as small for a leviathan. That's why the plane card makes everything small- it brings everything down to the scale where the leviathan seems big again.

This explanation even works (kind of) for the situation where you have a Segovian Leviathan in play and the Hippodrome plane in play: you summoned it somewhere where it was small, then planeswalked to Segovia with a small leviathan, which then got smaller. Unfortunately, it falls apart if you cast the card after planeswalking to Segovia, because if you summon one there, a local leviathan of normal size (for Segovia) should just swim over to you, no size change involved.

Oh well.

198068: Glimmervoid Basin.author: OpeeFomenom
198068: Glimmervoid Basin.text_parsed:
@LordCeviche
It doesn't say that stuff with shroud gets targeted, the ruling says the first ability, the one that copies the spell, doesn't count cards with shroud or other abilities that would prevent it from being targeted. It doesn't say the shrouded card can be targeted but rather that Glimmervoid Basen doesn't even count it when copying the spell even though its type might match the type specified to be targeted.

198068: Glimmervoid Basin.author: JimmyNoobPlayer
198068: Glimmervoid Basin.text_parsed:
@MANABURNWASGOOD: "it's copied for each...not on the battlefield...the spell could target." It's only copied for legal targets. So your Naturalize wouldn't be copied for any Artifacts or Enchantments in the graveyard or your hand, only the ones on the battlefield.

I really wish there was a spell that targeted cards in an opponent's library, but a quick search suggests there are none. Life's Finale would be very appropriately named if it targeted cards.
198068: Glimmervoid Basin.text_posted:
@MANABURNWASGOOD: "it's copied for each...not on the battlefield...[i]the spell could target[/i]." It's only copied for legal targets. So your Naturalize wouldn't be copied for any Artifacts or Enchantments in the graveyard or your hand, only the ones on the battlefield.

I really wish there was a spell that targeted cards in an opponent's library, but a quick search suggests there are none. [autocard]Life's Finale[/autocard] would be very appropriately named if it targeted cards.

198068: Glimmervoid Basin.author: Etsap
198068: Glimmervoid Basin.text_parsed: The only problem I have with this card is that I tend to build decks that don't include these kinds of spells. Why play Terminate when you can use Wrath of God? Rampant Growth effects don't target, and cards like Hex target too much. If I don't build around this then I tend not to be able to use it at all, or occasionally get stuck with a card that would trigger it and I don't want to because it would hurt me to do so. However, I did once win a game by playing Solemn Offering with Sanguine Bond out, stacking things so the Sanguine Bond was destroyed last. I don't think it killed everybody, but my life total was so high it didn't matter.

198069: Tazeem.author: Etsap
198069: Tazeem.text_parsed:
Just so everyone knows, as of this date there are actually four other promo plane cards that have not been added to Gatherer. You can find them elsewhere online, and none of them costs as much as this one.

Tazeem - Planechase release event promo.
Celestine Reef - Zendikar release event promo. It's Island Sanctuary/Stormtide Leviathan for the static ability and you get a Platinum Angel until the next planeswalk if you roll Chaos.
Horizon Boughs - Gateway promo (whatever that means). Everybody gets Seedborn Muse, and the Chaos is a triple Rampant Growth.
Mirrored Depths - The static ability is Planar Chaos, and the Chaos ability lets you cast the top card of an opponent's library without paying the mana cost (though you still have to flip a coin).
Tember City - The static ability is Manabarbs. The Chaos ability is "each opponent sacrifices a nonland permanent."

I usually don't like having my creatures exiled; I'd rather leave them in the graveyard and wait for my next recursion effect than actually use this ability.  The chaos is cool though, and it provides incentive to keep rolling, which is always good.

198076: Raven's Run.author: Etsap
198076: Raven's Run.text_parsed: Unfortunately, there are several problems with this plane. Wither is so often just not relevant to a given board state, though I do like what it does to a Blightsteel Colossus. The Chaos ability isn't a may, and this means you might have to target your own creatures if other targets are not available, and the ability does nothing if there aren't three creatures on the battlefield. Overall, a low-impact plane that at times discourages players from rolling, not what Planechase should be about.

198077: Cliffside Market.author: Etsap
198077: Cliffside Market.text_parsed: This card ought to swap the two triggers.  Exchanging a permanent every upkeep would be less swingy, and the chance to exchange life totals would provide a much bigger incentive to keep rolling.  On the other hand, strategy gets interesting if you don't take the highest life total, in anticipation that the next player will simply steal it from you.  Instead take the second or third highest and hope that it sticks so you don't get stuck with the lowest when somebody finally 'walks.

198078: Minamo.author: allmighty_abacus
198078: Minamo.text_parsed:
so apparently this is a plane now? Although the mere mention of kamigawa makes me cringe, this card is actually really useful in a planechase game. It makes decks with tons of cheap creature spells ungodly fast- think recycle, but without skipping the draw step and the painful hand size handicap- but also control benefits from this too. You will always have a card in hand, so unless you are completely tapped out your opponent(s) won't be sure if they are safe. I am always happy to walk to minamo, which is something I never would have thought possible for something that is supposed to be from that atrocity known as the kamigawa block.

While all spells benefit from the free cantrip, some spells just get awesome. Terminate becomes one of the nastiest kill spells in the game, as its cheap pricing means you will most likely be able to play the other terminate you drew. Recoil becomes hilarious, especially since you get it back if you get lucky with a roll (or someone else gets unlucky!)

What benefits the most, however, are the cascade cards. Keep in mind the card you cascade into is considered cast and triggers Minamos' first ability. For example, let's say you cast a bloodbraid elf. You draw a card, and then you cascade into violent outburst, draw another card and cascade into terminate. Oh, and you draw a card from that. So for {2}{R}{G} you got a 2/2 haste, killed a defender, gave all your stuff +1/+0 and drew three cards. You would have a hard time not winning with that kind of advantage.

198078: Minamo.author: psychichobo
198078: Minamo.text_parsed:
Oh God, there was this one time...

In one turn. ONE. One guy in the 5 way planechase game, who had a semblance anvil out with an artifact, played another one followed by hordes of cheap 2 cost artifacts. It was a Throne of Geth based proliferate infect deck.

He didn't use many lands in it and just blitzed through his deck, using Ichor Rats to poison everyone, then ripped through four artifacts with the throne and some untap stuff, some other cards like Steady Progress, and...

Long story short, the 'Play a spell, draw a card' effect of this had us all on 8 poison counters in one player turn. We didn't manage to kill him before his next turn.
198078: Minamo.text_posted:
Oh God, there was this one time...

In one turn. ONE. One guy in the 5 way planechase game, who had a [autocard]semblance anvil[/autocard] out with an artifact, played another one followed by hordes of cheap 2 cost artifacts. It was a [autocard]Throne of Geth[/autocard] based proliferate infect deck. 

He didn't use many lands in it and just blitzed through his deck, using [autocard]Ichor Rats[/autocard] to poison everyone, then ripped through four artifacts with the throne and some untap stuff, some other cards like [autocard]Steady Progress[/autocard], and...

Long story short, the 'Play a spell, draw a card' effect of this had us all on 8 poison counters in one player turn. We didn't manage to kill him before his next turn.

This card will always have a love/hate relationship with planechase players.

You'll love it when you're behind. You'll hate it when you're ahead.

So I guess you won't always hate it. =P

198079: Sanctum of Serra.author: sarroth
198079: Sanctum of Serra.text_parsed:
I must admit I wish this card didn't have the "may" clause on it. I think it would have much more interesting interactions (such as with Rain of Gore) or just to beat down players who enjoy massive amounts of life gain.

Otherwise I really like it. I've always been big on Serra's Realm and her angels. This plane's base ability works really well with having indestructible creatures, such as through Deathless Angel's activated ability or from Eldrazi Monument or with creatures that regenerate. Graveyard decks wouldn't mind the ability either. Then again, even without all of those, boards can get locked up a lot, especially with some of the slower styles encouraged by the Rise of the Eldrazi set, and taking out everything has always been a good way of resolving issues.

198079: Sanctum of Serra.author: MANABURNWASGOOD
198079: Sanctum of Serra.text_parsed:
Before I stopped playing 60 card magic (I primarily play edh now) there is a player in our group that usually relies heavily on artifacts and enchantmets. He'd typically play an enchantress build and used moat and the white card from Zendikar that puts angel tokens into play (the name escapes me at the moment).

We'd usually play Planechase and pray that this card came up clearing the board, mostly because he hated variant formats, and this card usuaully hurt him more than anyone else.

198079: Sanctum of Serra.author: Etsap
198079: Sanctum of Serra.text_parsed:
This plane is great when you're down, as you can always spend all of your mana hoping that you'll roll here and then off again, knowing it's the only thing that will save you from certain destruction. It gives you something to shoot for when all other hope is lost (unless of course, you've recently left here and know it's at the bottom of the planar deck).

The only thing I'd change is to use "your starting life total" instead of the number 20.

198083: The Dark Barony.author: Pollinosis
198083: The Dark Barony.text_parsed:
"On the plane of Ulgrotha, the vampire known as Baron Sengir controls a whole region of tightly clustered small villages, cast in perpetual night: The Dark Barony. Castle Sengir looms over this region, symbolic of the Baron's rule. The art, fittingly by the artist of most of the Sengir family's cards in Homelands, Pete Venters, shows the Barony from the point of view of one of the castle's balconies. Travel to this world only if you're prepared to take the reins of the Barony for yourself, dispensing edicts and mind-destruction effects with power-mad abandon."
http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtg%2Fdaily%2Fstf%2F54

198085: Turri Island.author: Pollinosis
198085: Turri Island.text_parsed:
"On the obscure plane of Ir is the mysterious Turri Island, a rocky isle beaten by choppy ocean waves, topped by a mountainous, rough-hewn stone fortress. This is the home of the Fomori, barbaric giants like the one seen on the Future Sight card Fomori Nomad (also illustrated by artist Raymond Swanland). The hulking Fomori leer over their battlements, threatening a boulder barrage toward anyone who should attempt entry—but many planeswalkers try, as the island is said to be a mana haven for summoning not only giants, but other cloudscraping creatures as well."
http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtg%2Fdaily%2Fstf%2F54

198087: Goldmeadow.author: ICEFANG13
198087: Goldmeadow.text_parsed:
Ah I remember this plane.

I dun like it, not because of any reason, I just don't

One game, I had 3 Essence Wardens and some other Fungus (4FA) and I had so much life. My friend was playing a Naya deck with Titanic Ultimatum as the biggest win condition. He has like 11 Goats from this plane and attacks me with Titanic Ultimatum

I survive, and take it all, I'm at like 20 life.

Next turn he does it again. I 'chump' some damage to try and live, but alas I was 1 toughness short.

I turn to my other 2 friends (currently its more like a 3 on 1) and ask if they have any toughness boosters, one says no (true). The other, who was newer, but did know what he was doing says no. He was playing a new green deck, so my mind says, well Giant Growth is extremely common for a new player, and I ask again.

"Are you sure you don't have any? Not even a Giant Growth?"

He says no again, so I die, a few minutes later he looks and says, did you mean THIS CARD?

Now I know this is on the internets, and you can't read exactly his emotions when he asked it, but he had one the entire time, and when I asked if he had THAT card he said no. During his turn (right after I died) he asked in a, "is this that card that would have helped but I wasn't paying a lick of attention?"

Yeah it was! HIOFhsiUgeiwaluhguewhailgh!

I hate that, when people give up in a planechase game. Come on lets make it 3 on 1 and see how his advantage goes. They both scooped, for lack of board.

While I'm telling some cool stories you can enjoy another one from last night.

Since then I have made a U/G Sliver deck for Planechase, I love me fungie friends, but people can get annoyed if I take a while (you know from having so much fungus counters)

Now I didn't make it so rape everyone, I love fun too. I based it on my favorite Sliver, Dormant Sliver, I think after this I'll write what the deck was like on it, I love Dormant Sliver.

Anyway, one other person was playing Jund Slivers, so we were kinda working together. My Dormant Slivers were letting him draw his deck, my deck is pretty heavy control, and I wasn't drawing great great. His field was growing wayyyy too big, he was just drawing and drawing (mostly because he was playing any sliver he wants, I always play a standard set, so this was Time Spiral Standard Slivers) however, he played the Homing Sliver So I cycled some of my more expensive slivers and got 4 Dormant Slivers, and I started to mill and mill and mill him, he couldn't play any more slivers and they all had defender.

I was quite pleased, I love beating superior numbers with brainpower.

Why didn't I die you ask? I had Slivers too.

I had Gaea's Blessings unfortunately I had one in my hand and one in the graveyard, and I forgot about the grave one, which caused me to lose first (I milled myself with Screeching Sliver to get the bonus effect before my draw, but there wasn't one)

I got 4th, but hey, I was happy.

Hope you enjoyed my cool bro stories

198090: Agyrem.author: Etsap
198090: Agyrem.text_parsed: This card's color imbalance makes it a little swingy sometimes, but it does still combo nicely with non-white cards like Sakura-Tribe Elder that self-sacrifice for benefit. If someone is playing white, then everyone else has strong incentive to roll the planar die, and if someone rolls chaos, then even the white player must eventually start rolling to get things moving forward. As far as getting stuck here, most decks should have no trouble rolling the planar die 3 times per turn. Two turns of this and there's only a 33% chance that you're still stuck here. After the third turn, it drops below 20% and after the fourth turn it reaches 11%. If more than one player is rolling three times, then this plane should be gone within two rounds.
198090: Agyrem.text_posted: This card's color imbalance makes it a little swingy sometimes, but it does still combo nicely with non-white cards like [autocard]Sakura-Tribe Elder[/autocard] that self-sacrifice for benefit. 198090: Agyrem.author: Pollinosis
198090: Agyrem.text_parsed:
"The ghosts of Ravnica's dead linger. Agyrem, commonly known as the Ghost Quarter, is an area of that city-plane where many spirits have collected, going about their business like nothing was amiss—except that they're dead. Planeswalkers who travel here may notice the spectral phenomena in the area; you may find that your creatures return to you instead of rotting in the dirt. You may even notice that the strictures and laws surrounding the tattered Guildpact still have power to prevent conflict in that district."
http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtg%2Fdaily%2Fstf%2F54

198096: Isle of Vesuva.author: Pollinosis
198096: Isle of Vesuva.text_parsed:
"Vesuva, a Dominarian island famous for its Doppelgangers and other Shapeshifters, is a region where nothing is as it seems. The shifting illusions can produce magical doubles of visitors there, and such doppelgangers are notoriously, murderously envious of the "originals." You can see post-apocalyptic Vesuva in Boros and Szikszai's Time Spiral art for Vesuva; here in Planechase the island is shown in a more pristine state. Note how the reflections in the water create a mirrored double of the towers and buildings of the town there."
http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtg%2Fdaily%2Fstf%2F54

198098: The Aether Flues.author: Pollinosis
198098: The Aether Flues.text_parsed:
"Iquatana is a world whose atmosphere is almost pure æther. The æther has a strange effect on the ecosystem here; creatures tend to warp and vacillate, turning into other organisms. The world's land is an expanse of chimneys and sinkholes that vent the plasma-like æther, supporting vapor currents ridden by the dreamlike, fickle-formed creatures.

Some planeswalkers visit here to attempt massive summonings, or to study the intelligent Iquati, who created the many Narcomoebae that float above the flues. The narcomoebae were created as living recollections, as the genealogical memory stores of the Iquati were sundered in some unknown past event."
http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtg%2Fdaily%2Fstf%2F54

198099: Bant.author: Ferlord
198099: Bant.text_parsed:
I noticed that 2009 planechase planes were very colour-based.

The mono-black one had The Dark Barony, which was Soot Imp on a planes and Grixis, which you could imagine what colours that helps.

Fast-forward to 2012, and all of the planes are much more all-reaching.

I suppose with Alara around, they kind of needed colour-based planes... I guess.

198100: Krosa.text_parsed:
"Krosa, a forested region on the Dominarian continent of Otaria, is home to ferocious beasts and races such as the Nantuko and the centaurs. The Wake of Power radiating outward from the Mirari artifact, planted there by the Barbarian-turned-Druid Kamahl, caused creatures to grow even more huge and violent. To this day the forest is a site of powerful creature-magic and amplified mana, recovering its vigor and magical potential as Greenseekers and other druids restore it to its former glory."
http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtg%2Fdaily%2Fstf%2F54

198101: Skybreen.author: Etsap
198101: Skybreen.text_parsed: The Chaos ability can be ridiculous if this plane is up during the early turns, and players can't cast spells so nothing else is happening but lots of rolls.  I think the spell restriction is very interesting overall, but this would play much better if the Chaos ability allowed you to interact with the first ability in some way, such as "Whenever you roll Chaos, any number of target players puts the top card of their library into their graveyard."  This way you can use the Chaos to influence which spell type can be cast.

I think the spell restriction is very interesting overall, but this would play much better if the Chaos ability allowed you to interact with the first ability in some way, such as "Whenever you roll Chaos, any number of target players puts the top card of their library into their graveyard." 198101: Skybreen.author: GrimjawxRULES
198101: Skybreen.text_parsed:
Pretty much a soft-lock. People can always choose to roll the planar die until they hit the planeswalk symbol though, but it might force someone to spend all of their mana on rolling the planar die instead of casting spells. Not exactly the most "fun" of the planes, but works pretty well if you're winning in terms of board position.
Also spent a bit of time wondering how this would work with Future Sight. Future Sight let's you play/cast the top card of your library, but Skybreen says you can't cast spells if they share a type with a card on top of a library. This way, if you try to cast a creature from the top of your library, I assume Skybreen would prevent you from doing that, even if you're the only player with a creature on top of their library and the next card in your library is a non-creature card.
To explain, what started this pondering was the fact that you move the card you're casting onto the stack when you cast it. This way, if the top card of your deck is a spell, you would move it to the stack, revealing a new card that might change which card type Skybreen affects. But then again, to move the top card of your library onto the stack, you have to be in the process of casting it, which I assume Skybreen would prevent altogether because, again, the card shares supertypes with itself.

So to conclude my pondering, I'm fairly sure you won't be able to cast cards through Future Sight while Skybreen is on the battlefield. I would like to have a judge's opinion on this just to be sure though, but as with any rules uncertainty, if you're not sure how it works, avoid doing it I guess.

198101: Skybreen.author: progenitus5
198101: Skybreen.text_parsed:
Welcome to the home of the Kalds
this IS the Norse plane
in their language, Heim means Home
and it was described as this in the Planes of Planechase article (http://www.wizards.com/magic/magazine/article.aspx?x=mtg/daily/stf/54)
"Skybreen, a blizzard-wracked mountain range on the plane of Kaldheim, is no place for the meek to visit. The scouring winds tear at gear and skin alike; the frigid temperatures congeal the blood and generate a frosty deterrent to magic; ice sheets, as sharp as straight razors, slice up travelers and form blind cliffs in the constant blizzards. The primitive barbarian race that survives here is not known for its hospitality or reasoned discourse; they practice both surgery and diplomacy with axes."
that is the stereotype of the Norse perfectly
And MaRo pretty much confirmed that a Norse place is coming...I'm a mythology addict, so you can trust me

198102: The Fourth Sphere.author: Pollinosis
198102: The Fourth Sphere.text_parsed:
"The dreaded Phyrexia, a plane overrun with creatures of foul artifice fused with twisted flesh, is at once one of the Multiverse's most unstoppable forces and one of its most horrifying places. Phyrexia is divided into nine nested spheres, each with a different grisly role. The fourth sphere of Phyrexia was both killing field and testing ground, where unnatural creations were set loose into a hellish artificial ecosystem to see which of them survived. If your circuitous route takes you here, prepare your minions for a hellish fight, and prepare yourself for casualties. Most planeswalkers will want to prepare to planeswalk away, as drawing the attention of Phyrexia can bring only doom."
http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtg%2Fdaily%2Fstf%2F54

willingly putting this in a Planar Deck is almost Suicidal without a guarantee to draw and play a Wheel of Sun and Moon before turn #5 (this is assuming you dont get milled by the chaos ability, and you are running a 60 card deck)
turn deck size
1 42 (drew 8, milled for 10)
2 31 (drew 1, milled for 10)
3 20 (drew 1, milled for 10)
4 9 (drew 1, milled for 10)
5 0 (drew 0, milled for 9)

*Playing with 4 players gives a minimum of 20 rolls should the person who has the anti-mill draws 2 lands and the wheel does roll once a turn. by turn 3, everyone will be rolling 3 times to get off the plane, giving a 1/6th chance that someone will roll a planeswalk

198105: Lethe Lake.author: Rendin
198105: Lethe Lake.text_parsed:
The entire self-milling drawback could be solved by simply having one instance of Emrakul, the Aeons Torn in your deck. I have him in an artifact deck and don't even use him (a lot of people I play with have decks centered around bringing out their Eldrazi of choice, usually Spawnsire or Emrakul. I find that annoyingly cheap) for combat; he just benefits me on the merit that mill decks that I play against are essentially crippled from the start. (Some of the people I play with have decks that do nothing but mill too, so it's a win-win. They're forced to lose horribly or not use cheap strategies, that is, just because Emrakul simply exists.)

With the drawback done and away with, this card has MASSIVE potential for decks centered around bringing cards back from the grave. It's like having a slightly limited Archmage Ascension without having to mess with counters, and it also doubles as a mill effect if that's what you're looking for.

198105: Lethe Lake.text_parsed:
"Arkhos is the plane represented by the Future Sight card River of Tears (also illustrated by Chris J. Anderson). It's a dreamlike world where night and day intermingle according to its own strange internal logic—check out the delicate quality of the light in the art. Near Lethe Lake on Arkhos, memories ebb away like the current of an old stone watercourse. Most mages tend to steer clear of the psychic ravages of the Lake, but surprisingly, some seek it out, believing they need to be cleansed of all remnants of the past in order to make their minds free for new magical creations."
http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtg%2Fdaily%2Fstf%2F54

198109: Eloren Wilds.author: Etsap
198109: Eloren Wilds.text_parsed: The nice thing about the severe downside of somebody rolling chaos on you is that you have twice as much mana to keep rolling the planar die for yourself and still have leftover mana to cast spells when you leave. 205267: Festering Goblin.author: Misago
205267: Festering Goblin.text_parsed: (Card Rating: 4.0) Festering Goblin can be an early game attacker while having the potential to become a pesky 1/1 creature's nightmare. By itself, the Festering Goblin is able to take out a 2/2 creature or finish off a creature granting an extra -1/-1. Because the ability does not do damage, Festering Goblin can get rid of small regenerators like Drudge Skeletons or Will-o'-the-Wisp. One drawback to this card is that the triggered ability is not optional. In other words, if your opponent has no creatures, he can destroy Festering Goblin in order to kill two of yours! In my black/red casual goblin deck, I try not to run goblins with a toughness of 1 that will be susceptible to this gruesome tactic, such as: Knucklebone Witch, Goblin Chirurgeon, etc. Even with the new change in rules from M10, Festering Goblin still is not as effecient as the "all so famous" Mogg Fanatic. The main reason for this is that Festering Goblin requires another card or action to occur, such as death in combat, for the -1/-1 effect to take place. On top of that, Festering Goblin cannot be used to deal 1 damage directly to an opponent like the Fanatic can. If you are running red in your deck, use the slightly better version of this card: Goblin Arsonist. (Posted By: Misago)

205268: Furnace of Rath.author: nickfifteen
205268: Furnace of Rath.text_parsed:
This card + X number of en-Kors (preferably at least Shaman en-Kor) + Mogg Maniac + Darksteel Plate on the Mogg Maniac + Pariah (attached to any en-Kor) = WIN

The idea would be to have en-Kors protecting yourself from attack, Pariah protecting yourself from targeted damage, Shaman en-Kors protecting other creatures, Darksteel Plate protecting the Mogg Maniac... ANY amount of damage done to you will not only NOT do any damage to you, but will also puke itself back to your opponent twice-fold. Two Furnaces means four-fold. Attacking for five means death.

You can hasten the process by using cards that deal X damage to ALL creatures in play (such as Slagstorm, Blasphemous Act or Chain Rection)... and even then all you need is a Mogg Maniac, Furnace and say only two or three en-Kors (3 damage to two en-Kors and a Maniac means 9 damage initially, then doubled to 18 by the Furnace, THEN doubled to 36 when it hits your opponent.) And THIS is pretty awesome AFTER the rule changes for the Furnace; before you were allowed to double the damage every time you redirected damage between en-Kors (because it's being "assigned" in each redirect), so a single damage meant death.

Poison damage is the only thing you need to worry about, but I'm sure there are ways to deal with it... I'm open to ideas on how to handle Poison damage in this situation...

205268: Furnace of Rath.author: Furnace_Fanatic
205268: Furnace of Rath.text_parsed:
A good friend of mine and I were having a discussion on favroite cards. The furnace was one of my first responces, but I cant fit it into a deck well enough where I dont die from it. So, he being a better magic player, helped me create a winner with many combos and good synergy. That deck even almost took a in house legacy tourny in my local cardshop (darn you prot red finalist). It ran like...

Furnace of Rath, Repercussion, Earthquake, Shivan Meteor, Skred, Fireblast, Rite of Flame, Lightning axe, Mogg Maniac, Spitemare, Heartless Hidetsugu(x1 for flaver), and Snow-Covered Mountains

It carries the possibility of a 1 turn kill but its nearly impossible. However it works like this if you go second or want someone out of a big multiplayer game... draw, play mountain, rite of flame1, rite of flame2, rite of flame3, Furnace, Mogg maniac, lightning axe your mogg.

205268: Furnace of Rath.author: InfoSponge
205268: Furnace of Rath.text_parsed:
Dangerous but great card. Cornerstone of my red deck for years. This + Repercussion + Pyroclasm / Earthquake / Inflame — make your opponents really suffer for those creatures!

I once won a large group game in a spectacular way with this: 2 Furnaces and a Repercussion out. I played Pyroclasm, then Inflame. That's 16 to each creature, and 64 to each player for each creature they control. I had 0 creatures, everyone else had at least one.

205268: Furnace of Rath.author: SAUS3
205268: Furnace of Rath.text_parsed:
Oh man. This is perfect! I even have this card in multiples! How have I not seen it before?!?!?!

This is going into my Tajic EDH when I get home. I used to have gratuitous violence and found it wasn't really pulling it's weight (not that many creatures in the deck, lots of burn and board wipes). I also used to have inquisitor's flail in the deck, but found it didn't add enough, only being good on Tajic, and being a piece of garbage compared to jitte (not its fault really, but it was a pretty easy swap).

With this card, I can make even more use of Tajic's indestructibility, and make my burns into epic game-enders.
Browbeat - take 10 damage or give me 3 cards.
Earthquake - kill all creatures without flying (most likely), and deal 2x damage to each player. Tajic gets through due to no blockers left for double damage as well.
Breath of darigaaz - becomes a monster board wipe + 8 damage to each player.

End the game in an epic blaze. Play this on a turn where I know I can get battalion. Play it when my opponent has few creatures (particularly when they are not a red deck).

205269: Grave Pact.author: Misago
205269: Grave Pact.text_parsed: (Card Rating: 4.0) Grave Pact is always a pleasure to play in a multiplayer format. If your oponent's do not have an answer for an enchantment in thier hand, any strategy they have involving even the most sturdy of creatures (i.e. Progenitus) will be fruitless. In light of the hefty 3 black mana required to cast it, Grave Pact is a rather difficult card to splash. Because having more than one in your hand equates to a dead card, Grave Pact makes my list of superb "one of's". Since you will be already running black, I recommend Demonic Tutor and Vampiric Tutor to make it seem like you are running three in your deck. If you are on a budget, Diabolic Tutor will suffice. In my favorite casual black/red goblin deck, I run 1 Grave Pact along with... 4 Mogg War Marshal, 2 Goblin Chirurgeon, 2 Skirk Prospector, and 1 Tuktuk the Explorer to ensure fodder plus an instance speed FREE sac. engine. I also run 1 Goblin Warrens to 99% ensure an opponent will NOT have a creature on the board! A Phyrexian Tower also works well to supply the sacrifice engine and black mana needed. On a side note, the artwork for the 8th edition version is fantastic. Check it out! (Posted By: Misago)

205269: Grave Pact.author: zerosavant
205269: Grave Pact.text_parsed:
Best Sac Trap card period.

Butcher of Malakir costs quite a bit more, but at the same time it only requires opponents to sacrifice rather than all players, so it becomes more applicable in team based multiplayer games. Not only this, but if Grave Pact gets disenchanted, it just leaves, whereas if butcher gets destroyed, his death triggers his own effect.

Even with these two caveats, I still say grave pact is better. But butcher i find to be an acceptable Standard alternative.

205269: Grave Pact.author: JaxsonBateman
205269: Grave Pact.text_parsed:
Oh Grave Pact, how you deserve to be a 5. This card basically reads: if you remove my creatures, you're giving me card advantage. If I sacrifice my creatures in a non-card-disadvantageous way, I'm giving myself card advantage. If I'm doing something fundamental to my deck - like saccing Eldrazi spawns or playing Fleshbag Marauder - with this out, I'm giving myself card advantage. If I play creatures with persist, I'm giving myself major card advantage.

And seeing as it hits everyone, it works just as well in multiplayer. If you're a casual gamer and can afford to, get a playset and throw them in black decks, making people cry. ^^ Even the simplest of combos - something like Reassembling Skeleton and Bloodthrone Vampire - becomes 1B: Bloodthrone Vampire gets +2/+2 and each opponent sacrifices a creature. That's a hell of an effect for 2 mana!

The only downside is the triple black, but hopefully that'll encourage people to play black (or go 2 color with mostly duals).

I think it's because battle ends in a vowel and axe begins with one, and if you don't know that its a compound word, the 'ea' would be pronounced as in 'read'.

war and hammer don't have any such issue, and are pronounced the same no matter how you combine them.

@Tezz

While it is true that complex cards are often rare, it is not true that simple cards are not rare. Rarity is the means by which wizards can control the frequency of cards appearing in limited. 205271: Relentless Assault.author: Gabriel422
205271: Relentless Assault.text_parsed:
It's time to let this awkward template die; we have better technology today and it's called double strike. Yes, I know the untap + extra combat phase has its own unique combo potential. But just as we should make Last Gasp instead of Nameless Inversion a core set staple, so should we make the following new card and start making cards based on it, instead of cards based on Relentless Assault.

"All creatures you control gain double strike until end of turn."

205272: Verdant Force.author: Diachronos
205272: Verdant Force.text_parsed:
Yes, Mycoloth makes more Saprolings at a time. The thing is, Mycoloth needs 1/1 counters to generate Saprolings, so you either need a way to give him some or Devour creatures. If you have to Devour, you need to have creatures on the field that you can afford to sacrifice.

On the other hand, Verdant Force generates a Saproling every turn instead of just yours.

Of course, there's no reason you can't have both of them in your deck :D

205272: Verdant Force.author: Wynzerman
205272: Verdant Force.text_parsed: This card splashes into Green decks better than Mycoloth because it doesn't require creature sacrifice to create creature advantage. Mycoloth needs a deck full of bears and 1/1s to run efficiently, and spamming small creatures tends to eat up hand advantage. 205272: Verdant Force.author: djbon2112
205272: Verdant Force.text_parsed:
@Kelrath: It's rated highly because, for the 11 YEARS of magic between when this was printed and Mycoloth (1997 to 2008), this WAS the most efficient, best token-producing fatty. Some of you new players complaining about old cards seem to be missing the fact that creatures only got really good in the last ~3 years. I just came back to the game this year, and one of the first cards I saw was Leatherback Baloth. And it blew me away. AN UNCOMMON! Why? It's a 4/5 for GGG! That was unheard-of when I played back in this era (~Stronghold to Odyssey)! Something like Mycoloth producing ~5+ tokens per turn was also unheard of! The reason is: they had always overestimated creatures and understimated removal. Now that that's changed, they can confidently print crazy creatures because any of them could easily die to removal.

4.5/5 for being one of my favourite creatures EVER, and for ~10 years of thinking the tokens only happened on MY upkeep (I'dve won a bunch more games had I really noticed >.<)!

The kind of person who revels in Verdant Force is usually the same person who is leery of devouring creatures with Mycoloth. They were designed for different people and shouldn't be judged on the same scale.

205272: Verdant Force.author: scumbling1
205272: Verdant Force.text_parsed:
Verdant Force has the advantage for almost always granting you a single token, as often your opponent will need to untap to throw a removal spell at his face. The best fatties guarantee a return on the investment, even if they get killed, with having haste or "enters the battlefield" triggers. While Verdant Force doesn't technically have one of them (and the initial return is small), it comes close. Creatures tend to be better designed nowdays, but the Force was good enough for it's time to see play along side Natural Order.

Comparitively, Mycoloth is sheer garbage. Not only does it lack the ability to immediately refund some of the mana you sink into it, it requires additional risk to do anything of use. The trend towards better design does not apply in this case.

205274: Nefashu.author: Mister_Tapwater
205274: Nefashu.text_parsed:
I think the idea behind this card is that he's better in combat than a 3-toughness creature would normally be because of his on-attack trigger. 3/x creatures can't actually block and kill him, and even your 6/6 only trades. Plus, you never really want to gang block him, since he will usually take down at least two creatures between his trigger and combat damage.

Whoever said that he dies to lightning bolt is right to point that out, but bear in mind that in Onslaught block red's one-mana burn spell was Shock.

Still, not a very exciting way to spend six mana.

205277: Broodstar.author: Lyoncet
205277: Broodstar.text_parsed:
In a void, this guy's probably a better game-ender for artifact decks than Master of Etherium since he's got evasion. Still, I'd say this is the worse card (not to say it's bad by any means). For comparison:

Broodstar:
Harder to chump block (either should kill anything in its path a few turns in, flying or no)
Possible to cast for UU
Having a high CMC is useful in a few cases

Master of Etherium:
3 CMC, can be played for U with two Etherium Sculptor (why wouldn't you run those in an artifact deck?) - basically it's always going to be cheaper
Very easy turn 2 3/3 or 4/4, racking up early damage
For the above reasons, much more useful against aggro decks, since you can start picking off their weenies quickly and easily
Can be tutored out on turn 5 with Tezzeret the Seeker with no mana acceleration, and earlier with acceleration, and he survives with one loyalty left
Fabricate
Tinker, if you're desperate
Played at instant speed with Master Transmuter
An extra draw with Vedalken Archmage
Helps with Metalcraft
Artifact creature lord, meaning you're likely making a lot of other creatures a lot more powerful; especially handy with Tezzeret's ultimate
Each after the first gives all others +2/+2
Protects your lands from being wiped if your opponent can turn permanents into artifact creatures, and lets you run, say, Mycosynth Lattice/March of the Machines for a one-sided Armageddon

Of all the advantages each has against the other, I'd say that the strongest by far is the ability of Master of Etherium to at very least slow down aggro decks during that perilous early game. Sure, it's more likely that Broodstar will connect for 8 on turn 6, but that doesn't matter much if you die on turn 4. Of course, if you're going heavy artifacts, what's to stop you from running both?
205277: Broodstar.text_posted:
In a void, this guy's probably a better game-ender for artifact decks than [autocard]Master of Etherium[/autocard] since he's got evasion.  Still, I'd say this is the worse card (not to say it's bad by any means).  For comparison:

[autocard]Fabricate[/autocard]

205291: Lodestone Myr.author: Krysto
205291: Lodestone Myr.text_parsed:
He's good friends with a friendly little Static Orb.

Tap the orb before your opponent's turn is over to "turn it off" so when your turn rolls around you untap everything.

= Opponent's can only untap 2 cards per turn - the orb with NONE of it's usual drawbacks.
Same goes for howling mine.

Thus Lodestone Myr DOES still work as an off switch for certain triggers on artifacts so that you can selectively apply effects to your opponents, but this is only on older cards/certain newer cards.

Cards worth "Turning Off":
Blinkmoth Urn - Only gives you mana
Genesis Chamber - Prevents opponents from gaining tokens
Howling Mine - Can prevent the additional draw for you or opponents
Static Orb - Can bypass its effect on you
Trinisphere - Allows 0-2 CMC artifacts to be played as normal

205297: Nuisance Engine.author: Atali
205297: Nuisance Engine.text_parsed:
@Concerned_Bystander
"artifact" is not capitalized in the token definition, thus it is a type, not a subtype. "Pest" is capitalized, indicating that it is a subtype.
So, written out in conventional format, the type line of the token would be "Artifact Creature - Pest"

205304: Serum Tank.author: Psuedonaut
205304: Serum Tank.text_parsed: Combos with Dross Scorpion, an Everflowing Chalice that taps for 3, two Corpse Curs, and an Ashnod's Altar. Then again, it doesn't really do anything that great. Sure, it's good if you've got infinite mana and infinite artifact untaps, but it's a 6 card combo for infinite mana, infinite artifact creature rotations, infinite draw, and infinite artifact untaps. The card itself isn't really good, only using amazing cards like Ashnod's Altar and Dross Scorpion and Everflowing Chalice really make it practical. It's usage of charge counter's is good with things like Power Conduit and Coretapper, as well as other charge counter things, at least.

205311: Thirst for Knowledge.author: scumbling1
205311: Thirst for Knowledge.text_parsed:
"Why is this restricted in vintage now? It doesn't really feel that overpowered to me"

Because Mana Drain is too good. Drain decks are a pillar of modern Vintage, and they threaten to choke out other archetypes when given a bunch of cheap draw and library manipulation. That's why they've also restricted Brainstorm, Ponder, Fact or Fiction and Gifts Ungiven. Otherwise, Drain decks just become too consistent.
205311: Thirst for Knowledge.text_posted:
[i]"Why is this restricted in vintage now? It doesn't really feel that overpowered to me"[/i]

Because [autocard]Mana Drain[/autocard] is too good. Drain decks are a pillar of modern Vintage, and they threaten to choke out other archetypes when given a bunch of cheap draw and library manipulation. That's why they've also restricted [autocard]Brainstorm[/autocard], [autocard]Ponder[/autocard], [autocard]Fact or Fiction[/autocard] and [autocard]Gifts Ungiven[/autocard]. Otherwise, Drain decks just become too consistent.

205311: Thirst for Knowledge.author: zk3
205311: Thirst for Knowledge.text_parsed:
@FoxArris:
Scu.mbling has it all right: as a 4-of, it gave blue decks too much consistency. Unrestricting this would prove too powerful and skew the field.
But let's see why it would be good still good. It recycles the blightsteel that found its way into your hand, and even gets a shuffle out of it (to redistribute early-game preordain scrys, jace's +1's, or vendillion cliques targets).
Because it digs three cards deep at instant speed, it's closest comparison is brainstorm. However, TfK puts the extra cards into your graveyard, which is more accessible than the top of your library. You also have fresh cards to draw your next turn, unlike brainstorming without shuffle effects.

All of these provide incredible synergy with what vintage drain decks want to do. It's not what this deck does at a moment, but all of these things put together that makes it so potent. It's like looking at brainstorm at face value. Both cards are not that great for what they obviously do, but their synergy is what makes it incredible.

205314: Wizard Replica.author: Magnor_Criol
205314: Wizard Replica.text_parsed:
It's interesting; look at the comments on the Mirrodin printing of this card, they're all quite positive. By contrast, most of the comments here are somewhat lukewarm.

I think you guys are underrating him. A tabled soft counter is great for playing some mind games with your opponent - it's a constant reminder to him that the next time he tries something fancy, you'll counter it. Yes it lets him play around it, but it can also cause him to slip up by over-thinking it.

The fact that it's a delayed soft counter on 3-toughness wings makes it a great card. He's a keystone part of why blue and artifacts work so well together.
205314: Wizard Replica.text_posted:

As much as I love this card, and I do love it, I have to admit that I can count the number of times it has made a difference on the fingers of one hand. If you get through with it in two-player, chances are you have already won, and in multiplayer it is a hate-magnet from hell.

205319: Mage Slayer.author: PrismFalcon
205319: Mage Slayer.text_parsed: Does this mean that it deals damage <u>before</u> combat starts? Does that count as combat damage? Or is it dealing combat damage as if it isn't blocked? I can think of a few combos based on not dealing or recieving combat damage, so I need to know which one it is.
205319: Mage Slayer.text_posted: Does this mean that it deals damage [u]before[/u] combat starts? Does that count as combat damage? Or is it dealing combat damage as if it isn't blocked? I can think of a few combos based on not dealing or recieving combat damage, so I need to know which one it is.

205319: Mage Slayer.author: Vinifera7
205319: Mage Slayer.text_parsed:
@PrismFalcon:
When attackers are declared, Mage Slayer's ability triggers and goes on the stack. Players get priority, and finally this ability resolves. So the creature equipped with Mage Slayer deals damage from this ability even before blockers are declared. The damage from Mage Slayer's ability is not combat damage, but the creature still deals combat damage normally during the combat damage step.
205319: Mage Slayer.text_posted:
[b]@PrismFalcon:[/b]
When attackers are declared, Mage Slayer's ability triggers and goes on the stack. Players get priority, and finally this ability resolves. So the creature equipped with Mage Slayer deals damage from this ability even before blockers are declared. The damage from Mage Slayer's ability is [b]not[/b] combat damage, but the creature [i]still[/i] deals combat damage normally during the combat damage step.

205319: Mage Slayer.author: Malnourished_Student
205319: Mage Slayer.text_parsed:
@ DlCK

Yes, you would gain the life from Lifelink. Lifelink does not specify combat damage, but any damage dealt by a creature with Lifelink will cause you to gain life (rules 118.3e & 702.13b).
205319: Mage Slayer.text_posted:
@ DlCK

205319: Mage Slayer.author: RazzmatazzTheGreat
205319: Mage Slayer.text_parsed:
If you're playing R/G, you've probably got access to some ramp. But let's be a little conservative, I don't like when people post ridiculous combos that will never actually happen in a real game. Anyway:
Turn 2-4: Get a Mage Slayer into play sometime during these turns
Turn 5: Cast Rhox
Turn 6: Equip Mage Slayer to Rhox and attack - 10 damage, even if your blocked. If you happen to have anything in hand that pumps for 5 or more, that's 20+ damage right there. And depending on your ramp suite, this could easily happen a whole turn faster.

Turn 5: Cast [autocard]Rhox[/autocard]
Turn 6: Equip Mage Slayer to Rhox and attack - 10 damage, even if your blocked. If you happen to have anything in hand that pumps for 5 or more, that's 20+ damage right there. And depending on your ramp suite, this could easily happen a whole turn faster.

205319: Mage Slayer.author: Sovereign_of_Planes
205319: Mage Slayer.text_parsed:
okay...

Omnath, Locus of Mana + Mage Slayer + Mark of Sakiko (or similar) + Furnace of Rath (or similar)

Omanth is 1/1 and gets +1/+1 for each {G} in your pool (also, {G} doesn't empty from your pool as turns and phases end so that's a huge plus)

Mark of Sakiko: whenever enchanted creature deals damage to player add that much {G} to your mana pool (see where im going with this yet?)

Furnace of Rath: whenever a source would deal damage to a creature or player, it deals twice that much damage.

So... Bring out the Furnace for 4, bring out Omnath for 3, and enchant him with Mark of Sakiko for 2, then attach Mage slayer for 3, and swing, then tap 2 floating {G}... your little, non-intimidating 1/1 Omnath deals a total of 25 damage in a single attack...

so cheap to get out for a properly made R/G deck

205319: Mage Slayer.author: smb379
205319: Mage Slayer.text_parsed:
So, I have a question, that I can't seem to find the answer to anywhere else. During one of my games, I had a 20/23 (or some such power... it was at least 20) Forgotten Ancient. I had equipped him with Mage Slayer and declared him as an attacker. The opponent I was attacking had 20 life, and responded by using Unsummon on my creature.

The game consisted of multiple players, and I'm 100% positive that he would not have used Unsummon if I had attacked another player. So, since the Unsummon was a response to me attacking, would Mage Slayer's effect have triggered (since the creature was attacking) therefore killing my opponent before Unsummon resolved?

I didn't really think about it at the time, so we just went with the fact that my creature was unsummoned, and therefore did no damage. But when I was reading about how the ability triggers during the declare attackers step, I wondered if I would've taken out that player.

Anyway, thanks for your help and responses. :)
205319: Mage Slayer.text_posted:
So, I have a question, that I can't seem to find the answer to anywhere else. During one of my games, I had a 20/23 (or some such power... it was at least 20) Forgotten Ancient. I had equipped him with Mage Slayer and declared him as an attacker. The opponent I was attacking had 20 life, and responded by using Unsummon on my creature.

The game consisted of multiple players, and I'm 100% positive that he would not have used Unsummon if I had attacked another player. So, since the Unsummon was a response to me attacking, would Mage Slayer's effect have triggered (since the creature was attacking) therefore killing my opponent before Unsummon resolved?

I didn't really think about it at the time, so we just went with the fact that my creature was unsummoned, and therefore did no damage. But when I was reading about how the ability triggers during the declare attackers step, I wondered if I would've taken out that player.

Anyway, thanks for your help and responses. :)

205319: Mage Slayer.author: JacG
205319: Mage Slayer.text_parsed:
@smb379
Yeah, your opponent died. Your triggered ability went on the stack, then his unsummon went on the stack. His unsummon resolves and your creature goes back to your hand, then your Mageslayer trigger resolves and he dies.
My girlfriend uses this in her Mayael the Anima EDH deck. Whenever she gets this on a Hamletback Goliath, everyone at the table groans.

205321: Bull Cerodon.author: Valakrie2040
205321: Bull Cerodon.text_parsed: I am really fascinated by this card and its younger counterpart, Cerodon Yearling. Both cards are simple and yet effective, however; I really wish that Wizards would have just made its converted cost 3RW. At 6cc and under I think both red and white may have better resources, and paying 6 for a creature that has no form of evasion and can be chump blocked is a tiny bit underwhelming when considering the opponent's possible threats on turn six (assuming that you are still alive by then, that is). Additionally, it would have truly made this card and Cerodon Yearling a “pair” when concerning their converted mana cost, abilities, power/cc ratio, and etc. Overall though, this is still a good card for what it does.

205321: Bull Cerodon.author: humor_love

I've got a 60-card deck using Naya colors. I was thinking about this card. I decided that this card might be worth using in a Boros-colored deck, but for a Naya-colored deck, I'd rather transform one of the colorless mana in the cost to a green mana and play Meglonoth. Meglonoth doesn't have the Haste, but Meglonoth doesn't need it. For 6, it's just a much better creature in most circumstances.

(As I referred to above, the Cerodon may be better in Boros-flavored decks, which, with more Red than Naya, probably have more Haste/burn type stuff, and can probably benefit much more than Naya from a 5/5 with Haste.)

205322: Death Baron.author: Silverware
205322: Death Baron.text_parsed:
Death Baron is a solid zombie lord. He meets all the requirments for the standard lord:

3cmc, +1/+1 to other creatures of its tribal type, and an additional unique bonus.

Death Baron's deathtouch is very usefull for zombie tribal and skeleton tribal, it is slightly more obvious why he is so effective for skeleton tribal (regenerating creatures, and creatures that return to play are very deadly with deathtouch).

I run Death Baron in a zombie tribal deck along side Lord of the Undead, and Undead Warchief. As far as lords go this one runs best with creatures with low cmc due to it having a static ability, being realitivly cheap compared to Undead Warchief (1 mana cheaper) and works well with festering goblin, not much is scarier than a 1/1 zombie with death touch for that can take down a huge creature and another small creature with it.

All in all Death Baron is a good lord, A very solid 3 drop in Zombies OR Skeletons (it is a shame that it isn't a skeleton in addition to being a zombie).

A superb artifact lord.
Playing the right lands can have another great impact. Aside from the obvious choices - artifact lands like Seat of the Synod or Darksteel Citadel, i like him most with artifact manlands, which get stronger from him and make him stronger while animated:
Mishra's Factory, Blinkmoth Nexus or even Inkmoth Nexus.
Semblance Anvil and Vedalken Archmage are also nice additions for reduced (up to nullified) costs and card draw.
Another master for or a free Steel Overlord that pumps your master(s) immediately and in your following turns all your artifact creatures doesn't sound half bad for example.

205326: Relic of Progenitus.author: JaxsonBateman
205326: Relic of Progenitus.text_parsed: The only thing that might make some sort of mill deck playable in standard atm. With the three eldrazi legends locking out most normal mill strategies, all a player needs to do atm is keep one in the side (if they have none in the main) for the rare mill deck they come up against. Of course, RoP is one of the only cards which both stops the eldrazi coming back AND makes sure the hard work you've done up to that point stays done (there are a few instant speed abilities and cards which remove singular cards in a graveyard from the game, but then, it'd really suck to have a ~20 card Traumatize go to waste when RoP stops it from doing so).

205328: Cranial Plating.author: Antsache
205328: Cranial Plating.text_parsed:
@TomFly

You declare all your attackers simultaneously and they all do damage simultaneously - you can't use the "attach" ability to pop it from one to the other and give both its buff... unless one has first/double strike, anyway, in which case you can move it between first strike and main combat damage steps, which can be REALLY nice.

Without access to first strike, you can still swap which creature it's on in response to their block, which gives you all sorts of options. You can move it to kill a more important blocker, or if they let one of your little guys through you can move it there to get around the block altogether.

Of course, attentive opponents will see this coming unless you get really tricky with how you make the mana for it, but no matter - it makes blocking your attack much more difficult, and allows you to bump it back to a small creature that didn't attack to have a powerful blocker on defense, if needed. (Of course in the latter case a second main phase equip is probably better, but if you have nothing better to do with the mana holding it up for the instant-speed equip may be relevant; you never know.)

On a side note: they've been trying to figure out how to make auras playable without just increasing the power level pretty much forever. Having a few that could jump around at instant speed might be worth exploring. (I'm sure they've done that before somewhere, but I can't think of it off the top of my head) Anyway, that would bring them closer to equipment, which may not be desirable, but the instant speed and the inability of auras to stick around without being attached to something could maintain a pretty strict differentiation. Maybe compensate by sticking the auras with color restrictions for what they could enchant, or something (which would really set them apart flavor-wise from the colorless nature of most equipment).

205329: Door to Nothingness.author: CorkBulb
205329: Door to Nothingness.text_parsed:
This card is both funny, stupid, lame and awesome all rolled into one!

The whole "target player loses the game" cracks me up every time I read it. The mana cost is just so rediculous the card is usually dismissed.

It enters the battlefield tapped, so opponents have ONE TURN to get rid of it, assuming you have the mana. Only an imbicile would play it early and leave it just sitting there because as soon as your opponent sees you've almost got that last mana, he will burn it. Play it AFTER you have it so he is like OH NOES!

And if you have , you deserve to win the game. Actually no, you don't win, your opponent LOSES!!!! Talk about "YOU LOSE"....

Nothing like this card in the Metallic Dreams Planeschase deck in multiplayer when you do actually have the mana. The feeling of power being able to choose someone's fate with one move is priceless, and so is the feeling of having everybody beg for their lives. "Who shall I end today"? Mind you, out of the 100 or so games ive played with that deck, I've only used it TWICE. So I wouldn't count on it.

The other hilarious thing about it is that it makes "target opponent" lose the game AT INSTANT SPEED!!! Hahaha! You can just have it sit there until you decide to make "target opponent" lose, In a duel they would just concede but everybody will hold their breath in a multiplayer game. And if someone goes to burn it you can just activate it!

5/5 for usefulness, hey, you'll win the... I mean your opponent will LOSE the game XD
5/5 for humor. Its the only card ever printed that has a targeted player losing ability XD
2/5 For versatility, can only be used in a WUBRG deck
1/5 for reliability. Just costs too much and its too varied. you need TWO of every color. Sometimes I have a hard time getting two of ONE mana. You'll usually die before it happens.
3/5 total

The feeling of power being able to choose someone's fate with one move is priceless, and so is the feeling of having everybody beg for their lives. "Who shall I end today"? Mind you, out of the 100 or so games ive played with that deck, I've only used it TWICE. So I wouldn't count on it.

The other hilarious thing about it is that it makes "target opponent" lose the game [b]AT INSTANT SPEED[/b]!!! Hahaha! You can just have it sit there until you decide to make "target opponent" lose, In a duel they would just concede but everybody will hold their breath in a multiplayer game. And if someone goes to burn it you can just activate it!

5/5 for usefulness, hey, you'll win the... I mean your opponent will LOSE the game XD
5/5 for humor. Its the only card ever printed that has a targeted player losing ability XD
2/5 For versatility, can only be used in a WUBRG deck
1/5 for reliability. Just costs too much and its too varied. you need TWO of every color. Sometimes I have a hard time getting two of ONE mana. You'll usually die before it happens.
3/5 total

205331: Pentad Prism.author: Tempted_Johnny
205331: Pentad Prism.text_parsed:
Compared to other 2cmc Mana-artifacts (Talismans and Signets for example), this has one obvious advantage; it pushes your available mana on turn 3 to 5 instead of 4. Even if you're only trying to ramp to a 4-drop (let's say Tezzeret, Agent of Bolas), with this you can cast it and still have an extra mana available for Spell Pierce or Turn Aside to protect your investment.

Another subtle advantage of this card is the fact that you can tap out to play it and still have mana available on your opponent's turn just in case you need to answer a threat.

205333: Tornado Elemental.author: ClockworkSwordfish
205333: Tornado Elemental.text_parsed:
I dunno about taking this over Thorn Elemental; good ol' Thorn Elemental has the force of nostalgia on its side and wins you the game in an even three turns. Still, this card is incredibly good. I have never had this fail to kill all fliers on the opponent's side (I don't have any, usually), and this is a good thing. More than once, this has bailed me out of a next-turn loss. Hitting for a reliable six is also very good. I feel like a living tornado should fly, but hitting the opponent directly is just as good, if not better, though worse flavourwise (Just why does it hurt your opponent from a distance?). I can understand that Thorn Elemental shoots thorns, but what does Tornado Elemental fling? Cows?
A 6/6 for , even with its direct-damage ability, would be a bit of stretch (Thorn Elemental is 7/7 for the same cost, after all), but add in the kill-fliers ability and it's a heck of a deal.
Top it all off with the stellar art; that is definitely what a tornado-as-a-creature would look like. The fact that I like Thorn Elemental more makes this a 4.5/5, but the layperson would give it 5.

205333: Tornado Elemental.author: OpeeFomenom
205333: Tornado Elemental.text_parsed:
@ClockworkSwordfish

I think it's ability is perfectly flavorful. It's probably because you're comparing it to a card like Thorn Elemental that you're imagining the need for it to fling something. When I read the text I pictured it as, it's a tornado, your creature can try and block a TORNADO but it's not going to be able to stop it.(Unless of course it deals 6 damage and destroys it and even then unless it has first strike, it's not going to block it.)

It wouldn't have made sense for it to have flying because while it's a tornado, it's still in contact with the ground at practically all times. And if it had "unblockable" that still wouldn't make sense because there's no reason a creature can't "try" to block a 50 ft tornado. It's not exactly a discreet creature.

Of course, if you still want to imagine something being flung think of it this way, the creature is fighting it at its base while it's shooting lightning at you from its eyes.

205333: Tornado Elemental.author: WhiteWizard42
205333: Tornado Elemental.text_parsed:
Eved: "Did you know there are only 27 Flying creatures in the game that would survive the 6 damage? "

When you make statements like this, say when they're made because the number's always going up. As of M12 release, for example, I can find 44: 33 flyers with 7 or more toughness, 5 with unconditional protection from green, Phantom Flock (with at least 2 counters on it), Iridescent Angel, Dawn Elemental, Swans of Bryn Argoll, Darksteel Gargoyle, and Commander Eesha.

Also, Pristine Angel if it's untapped, and Voice of All if you chose Green. Mist Dragon can dodge it too.

I may still be missing some, but that's a good starting point.

205334: Suntouched Myr.author: Aaron_Forsythe
205334: Suntouched Myr.text_parsed:
Aaron's Random Card Comment of the Day #22, 10/26/10

This most-vanilla sunburst card gives me a great excuse to talk about the mechanic in general.

I designed the sunburst mechanic; it was one of the first I ever made. I was still working as the website editor for MagicTheGathering.com at the time, and Mark Rosewater asked me to be on the Fifth Dawn design team because he figured the experience would let me generate a few interesting articles. Little did either of us know I’d be competent at design!

My thought process for sunburst went something like this: “By the time this set comes out, players will be able to make a deck entirely of artifacts, including 24 artifact lands. That deck will be able to produce all five colors of mana, especially if you played a bunch of Myr. Wouldn’t it be neat if that meant something? Also, in limited, having a card pool full of artifacts often lets you be a little loose and free with your colored mana and play the best cards. How can I make that open-ended mana matter on some of the artifacts?”

The latter half of that thought was probably a bit too “Spiky,” as I believe the default for most players when handed a pool with tons of artifacts is to play as few colors as possible, not as many. But as far as a third-set mechanic that shook things up and fit into the block’s flavor goes, I rather like sunburst.

I mentioned in my post on Vedalken Engineer that the Darksteel team helped out sunburst by allowing that card to produce colored mana. Very nice. But the biggest barrier to sunburst working well in draft was also in Darksteel--the cycle of “affinity for basic land” Golems (Razor Golem, et al.). I’m not sure why these cards were so important--they were the only affinity cards that referenced anything other than artifacts in the entire block--but the Darksteel team was committed to printing them even once the problem with sunburst was explained. Personally, I’d have ditched the Golems to let the next set shine, as the Golems weren’t pulling a ton of weight anyway. But I’m biased.

So players ended up drafting these powerful Golems highly and playing one- and two-color decks, and then had little interest in drafting sunburst in pack three, which made the set feel really tangential to the prior sets instead of integrated. And thus, block planning was born.

Even now in R&D, sunburst is kind of maligned, I think unfairly. Personally I think it can come back; it doesn’t even necessarily have to go on artifacts.

I also think that if the recent change to drafting last-set-first was in effect during MD5, sunburst could have been a killer archetype and not something that you gambled/lucked your way into. Fifth Dawn was certainly on my mind as we discussed implementing that upcoming change.

Oh, as for Suntouched Myr specifically, it was submitted at 2 mana. Both versions are interesting in limited.

205334: Suntouched Myr.author: johnnyboyy
205334: Suntouched Myr.text_parsed:
@Aaron_Forsythe
If you plan on reintroducing the sunburst mechanic what you need to do is make it very good if all colors are spent to play it. ie it gets added evasion (flying, landwalk, etc) or a power boost in another way. Assign some form of sunburst counter( maybe even a charge counter for interesting casual/commander play) for all colors being used, or a maximum amount of colors being used. then assign it a base creature statistic so that it doesnt die from counter removal. i can honestly say i loved the concept of sunburst. i have always loved five colored decks because they are challenging yet rewarding to run. however there were no commons or uncommons with sunburst that even remotely warranted running in any deck. a mana specific 3/3 for 3 is incredibly undewhelming. where as a 3/3 or even a 2/2 that if i payed 3 specific i would instead get a 5/4 or 4/4 trample would have been much more exciting as a player. giving the cards a "sunburst counter" would leave them open to counter removal, this is a strong balancing point for the mechanic, your oppenent can potentially depower your cards which some players may not like but would make slightly more powerful, all color mana "suggested" cards more printable. with sunburst it was a big let down to have 3 creatures in play that were all extrememely vulnerable to a single erradicate (sorry if this is the wrong card name, its darksteel 3BB remove all counters from all permants and tokens from the game) no one likes getting hit with a 5 mana one sided board sweep in limited. the only cards with sunburst i even recall being entertaining or useful were over costed immensely for what they required or did. namely solarion with his ability to get huge fast and sun-crusher with his creature slaying ability.

205334: Suntouched Myr.author: unspeakable
205334: Suntouched Myr.text_parsed: People are rating this card strictly on a power basis, which is idiotic.  For a common in an artifact set, this was a very interesting and well balanced card, which I played in numerous limited games.  With regard to comparisons to spouting thrinax, these cards would rarely be considered in the same format, and besides, spouting thrinax is only useful in a R/G/B deck, whereas the sountouched myr is potentially useful in any multicolored deck.  WOTC can print more powerful cards easily; printing creative and balanced cards is a much more interesting challenge, and much better for the game in the long run.

205335: Arcbound Crusher.author: Mode
205335: Arcbound Crusher.text_parsed:
Official oracle wording and dark artifact design.
Now i like this fellow even more.

And it has an incredible combo potential.
When used with Genesis Chamber, his ability will trigger for each creature at least one.
It can have a save start with Sword of the Meek, works even better if you add Thopter Foundry, and can become an infinite trampler if you use Mana Echoes as well. Too many cards required for this loop to consider using it, i know, but most of them already do a good job by themselves in the right deck.

And never forget it's all Modular on him.
Once he dies just move the counters and get another fattie. A flying Thopter for example.

205337: Darksteel Forge.author: Ajbcool
205337: Darksteel Forge.text_parsed:
My stepdad has this colorless artifact deck that mainly uses the Urzatron for his mana. At first, he had pre-8th Edition cards only, and thus not any access to the Mirrodin artifact support. But now...

His deck was changed forever. It went from a basic artifact toolbox to a combo deck with the Forge and Blinkmoth Urn at the center of it all. Pariah's Shield was taken out because it made everything much too easy, and Platinum Angel was never even considered because it was even cheesier (He's putting the Shield back in though, as it's very helpful).

The Forge has shaped Mirrodin....and that Artifact deck.

205337: Darksteel Forge.author: stygimoloch
205337: Darksteel Forge.text_parsed: Certainly, when you have nine mana free, pretty much anything you cast should be able to win you the game. But in many casual environments - where 'if' and 'when' you win are less important than 'how', and how many lulz are generated along the way - this is the nuts. An excellent example of a Johnny/Timmy card: it has an absolutely gigantic effect yet doesn't actually do anything useful without other cards to go alongside it. Spike generally couldn't care less, but that just meant he could trade it away for the Arc-Slogger Timmy didn't want, and everybody wins.

205337: Darksteel Forge.author: Artscrafter
205337: Darksteel Forge.text_parsed:
@PhyrexianLobbiest:

Turn 6: Hold action, then respond to Turn to Dust by using Master Transmuter to bounce and replay the forge and the angel (using the elixir to untap the transmuter) so they aren't the same targets that the spell had selected. Laugh uncontrollably.

The sequence can be done earlier than that with a few more cards.
Turn 1: Island. Optionally play whatever if you have it.
Turn 2: Island, Vedalken Engineer
Turn 3: Any land, Etherium Sculptor, tap the Engineer to play Thousand-Year Elixir.
Turn 4: Any land, Master Transmuter, bounce the sculptor for Darksteel Forge, untap the transmuter with the elixir, bounce the elixir for Platinum Angel.

Takes every card in hand and nearly every draw to pull off so it'll probably never happen, but there you go.

The only things that can potentially shut this card down is exile and being forced to sacrifice an artifact. There are ways of turning this card into a creature (Tezzeret, Agent of Bolas , March of the Machines ,etc) and then using something cheesy to get rid of it, such as Condemn , Path to Exile , Journey to Nowhere ,etc. Parasitic Implant may also work.

Thus, be sure to have many Cancels (or variations of it) on hand. Or simply use Venser, the Sojourner/Karn Liberated .

205338: Vedalken Engineer.author: ICEFANG13
205338: Vedalken Engineer.text_parsed:
@ C0nker3

That doesn't work for a two reasons:

1 Veldalken will only give mana that can be used for Artifacts, Crab Umbra is an Enchantment.

2 Training Grounds only decreases the cost of effects to creatures, Crab Umbra's ability is from the Enchantment, for instance, you can put it on an opponent's or allies' creature, they cannot untap it, but you can.

In the same idea, you can use Training Grounds to decrease the cost of Umbral Mantle because it grants the ability to the creature while it is equipped. That would give you an unlimited/unlimited Veldalken Engineer, if he was an artifact (since he has to be an artifact to use the mana for his ability that has been granted to him). You could also use Voltaic Construct in an infinite mana way, as well as Jandor's Saddlebags if it was a creature and an artifact.

205339: Sarcomite Myr.author: Dr.Pingas
205339: Sarcomite Myr.text_parsed:
I think people took the easy road in predicting this card. Yes, Mirrodin is the ONLY plane confirmed to have Myr, but there has never been a mention of Sarcomite or the Telchor to my knowledge, and as such, there was no real indication beyond creature-type that this bugger has anything to do with Mirrodin/New Phyrexia.

My assumption is that, without Memnarch, the myr either sought another master, or were found, and were then redesigned in a similar method as earlier Slivers (it is important to note, however, that it seems to be a blend of mechanical and biological life, so it may yet appear once New Phyrexia gets it's act together and attempts to expand more.)

It's a trap!

I waited for generous Instant or Sorcery subtypes for ages, finally we are provided with it.

The regular casting cost is rather fortunate though, but still playable.

205343: Whiplash Trap.author: Oleander
205343: Whiplash Trap.text_parsed: Note to Mode: There has previously been a subtype for instants and sorceries, found in Kamigawa: Arcane. Arcane was a subtype tacked onto several instants and sorceries, and it was most noted for the Splice Into Arcane ability on several spells, which allowed you to pay a cost, reveal the splicing card, and the effect gets added to the Arcane spell spell being played. Several creatures also were affected by the playing of Arcane spells, such as the cycles of the Baku and the Onna spirits, and there are several more I can't even recall at this time. Point being, subtypes to Instants and sorceries isn't new, it's just extremely uncommon.
